reason: The algebraic identity is presented unclearly: 'k^{underline{j}}/k\! = k\!/(k-j)\!/k\! = 1/(k-j)\!' has ambiguous notation. The expression 'k\!/(k-j)\!/k\!' can be parsed as either k\!/((k-j)\!*k\!) = 1/((k-j)\!) or (k\!/(k-j)\!)/k\! = 1/(k-j)\!. While the second parsing is correct, the proof should explicitly state: (1) k^{underline{j}} = k(k-1)...(k-j+1) = k\!/(k-j)\! by definition of falling factorial, then (2) dividing by k\! gives k^{underline{j}}/k\! = [k\!/(k-j)\!]/k\! = 1/(k-j)\!. The current presentation conflates these steps with ambiguous notation.
